name: Income
description: Understanding sources of income and salary structure.
card_title: Where does your money come from?
learning_text:
Your income is the starting point of all your finances. It could be your salary, freelance earnings, or even pocket money. Knowing your exact take-home amount (after taxes and deductions) helps you plan better.

Tip: Many people confuse gross salary with net salary. Always plan based on what actually hits your bank account.
quiz_question: If your gross salary is ₹50,000 but ₹8,000 is deducted for taxes and PF, how much should you use for budgeting?

name: Expenses
description: Fixed vs variable expenses and tracking them.
learning_text:
Expenses fall into two buckets:

• Fixed: Rent, EMIs, subscriptions – these stay the same every month.
• Variable: Food, shopping, entertainment – these change based on your choices.

Tracking both helps you spot patterns. Most people underestimate variable expenses by 20-30%!
quiz_question: Which of these is a fixed expense?

name: Budgeting
description: Creating a simple monthly budget (50-30-20 style).
learning_text:
A budget doesn't have to be complicated. Try this:

• 50% for needs (rent, groceries, bills)
• 30% for wants (entertainment, dining, shopping)
• 20% for savings and debt repayment

Example: If you earn ₹40,000, that's ₹20,000 for needs, ₹12,000 for wants, and ₹8,000 for savings.
quiz_question: With a ₹60,000 salary using 50-30-20, how much goes to wants?

name: Savings
description: Saving a percentage of income every month.
learning_text:
The secret to saving? Do it first, not last. As soon as your salary comes in, move a fixed amount to savings before you spend on anything else.

Even ₹2,000/month adds up to ₹24,000 in a year. Start small, stay consistent.
quiz_question: When is the best time to transfer money to savings?
quiz_options: End of month if anything is left
Only when you get a bonus

name: Emergency Fund
description: Building 3-6 months of expenses as safety buffer.
learning_text:
Life throws surprises – job loss, medical bills, urgent repairs. An emergency fund is money set aside just for these moments.

Aim for 3-6 months of your monthly expenses. If you spend ₹25,000/month, target ₹75,000 to ₹1,50,000. Keep it in a savings account you can access quickly.
quiz_question: If your monthly expenses are ₹30,000, what's a good emergency fund target?

name: EMI
description: Equated Monthly Instalments and how interest works.
learning_text:
EMI = Equated Monthly Instalment. When you take a loan, you pay it back in fixed monthly chunks that include both principal and interest.

The catch: In early months, most of your EMI goes toward interest, not the actual loan. A ₹10 lakh loan at 10% for 5 years means you pay about ₹2.75 lakh just as interest!
quiz_question: In the early months of an EMI, what does most of your payment go toward?

name: Risk
description: Risk vs return, volatility, and risk capacity.
learning_text:
Higher potential returns usually mean higher risk. A savings account is safe but grows slowly (~4%). Stocks can grow 12-15% but can also drop.

Your risk capacity depends on: age, income stability, and whether you have an emergency fund. Only invest what you can afford to not touch for 5+ years.
quiz_question: Which investment typically has higher risk AND higher potential return?

name: Mutual Funds
description: Basics of mutual funds and SIP investing.
learning_text:
A mutual fund pools money from many people and invests it in stocks, bonds, or both. You don't pick individual stocks – a fund manager does it for you.

SIP (Systematic Investment Plan) lets you invest a fixed amount monthly. ₹2,000/month at 12% for 10 years can grow to about ₹4.6 lakhs!
